name: Madison S.
comment info: This graph is a very unique application of simple data collecting. In addition to providing us all with information concerning the travel efficiency, the commuter has also created a hobby which can occupy her time taking said train. Fortunately, many times the train is not excessively late as there are many gray areas in the scarf. In addition, these usually come in larger blocks of color symbolizing a longer span of days where the train was not too late. The pink areas are interspersed less often than the grey, but they occur regularly enough that one can assume that this train runs behind schedule for about a third of the time it runs. The red spaces, representing the longest wait time for trains or delays in both directions occurs much less often except in one outlier. On the right side of this graph, there is one solid chunk of red. This could represent a time when the transit system was dealing with renovations, working on a light schedule, or dealing with inclement weather, such as a season's worth of snow. Either way, there was a major obstacle in the Munich transit system which caused the train to be excessively late during that period. A good headline would be, "Weaving in and out of traffic".

name: Madison S.
comment info: In this graph, I do not see something that looks like a graph at all. In all honesty I see a scarf. It is broken up into three separate colors: red, white, and blue. It could just be the weaver's preference of fabric, but I believe that it could relate to the different sides of the political spectrum. Rarely are the red and blue pictured next to each other, almost always separated by a stripe of white, a barrier of sorts. This could represent how most times, democrats and republicans are unable to work together to form policy in America. However, I do not know what the purpose of the width of the stripes means in this case. It probably represents some form of data, but I am unsure of whether it relates to laws being passed, or percentages of people getting laws passed.

name: Gabriel Wright
comment info:
1.) As the timings of the delays are relatively interspersed and the only major delay seems to be in one spot, perhaps the delays are rarer than the graph implies at first glance. And the most significant delay, occurring only once, may have been because of some extraneous circumstance. A holistic critique of the train system should look to account for these factors if they are present. 

2.) The pink areas are far more concerning than the red ones, as these "minor, yet still significant" delays are very common. Although there may be an expectation set that some delay will occur, it's very clear the train operators could be making some changes to improve the efficiency of the train.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
I see that there are many responses from California students, many from Rialto but undoubtedly from other places, too.  

Do you have public transportation in your area?  Possibly school buses?  Or, you could use highway congestion data.  How could you find data on transportation reliability and represent it in a graph?  

If you are not up to knitting a graph, you could use colored pencils with graph paper.  Also, quantitative data can be displayed in the more conventional histograms, bar graphs (if data is divided into categories), and time series.  

We'd love to see your data visualizations.

name: Moderator Jen
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graph:  “Scarf Make Train Look Bad” by SlickNinja of Baltimore, “Knitting Congestion Into Art” by G. McBride of Denver, and the trio from New Hampshire – “Weaving Through Heavy Traffic” by Daniel and Nate, “Warming Up with Delays” by Nathaniel, and “Knitting Through the Rows of Traffic” by Greg.

You can continue to post responses. Dig deeper into this graph. Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, Feb. 28 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphs, and one Stat Nuggets.

The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, FEB. 28, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, March 6!   The topic:  VAPING.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to What's Going On In This Graph? 

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who rides the Boston’s slowest and most unreliable T (T is what we call our subways that go above and below ground) in Boston, and Jennifer Mueller of St. Louis, who drives the twenty (or thirty depending on delays) minutes to work every day.

I wonder if this blew up online... This woman combined an older skill of knitting with new, fresh, original thought. name: Cory G
comment info: I noticed a few things about this graph. Firstly, there is a period in it where there was a delay of over 30 minutes for around a month in a row. Additionally, there are very many periods of 5 days in a row with grey. These are most likely periods of work days, Monday through Friday, where there are a lot of people commuting to work, increasing the number of time delays. I also noticed that there are periods of multiple days in a row with pink following the gray areas, meaning that there isn't very much traffic on the weekends in this area. I firstly wonder what could have inspired this scarf to be? Why did the creator decide to make this scarf based on their commute to work times? There are a lot of questions that can be asked about why this scarf was created and how inspiration was found to create it. I believe that in this graph a person is commuting to Munich for whatever reason, and that during their trips they are encountering a bit of traffic on the work days because there are also other people that are attempting to get to Munich to work. The period where there was an extended period of 30+ minute delays was most likely a main road closure. There is probably one main road that goes into Munich, and a side road or two. Since the main road was closed down, there was more traffic forced into the side roads, causing greater traffic backup and more time to get through the increase in traffic.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Cory G --
Great question:  Why a scarf graph?  Think of the alternatives – a time series or histogram.  Or, maybe just write about the delays.  How does a scarf graph compare to the other ways to communicate the data?  
Come back tomorrow afternoon when we will share the article that included this graph plus other articles that discuss scarf graphs – a mini-rage in the stat community.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of  “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  
Today’s graph shows the length of daily delays for 2018 on what should be a 40-minute commute between Munich and a Bavarian town.  The commuter knitted two rows each day.  Grey is for delays under 5 minutes.  Pink is for delays 5 – 30 minutes.  Red is for delays over 30 minutes or delays in both directions.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, give us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  
Plus, please have your students share with us a catchy headline that captures your ideas about the graph. 
Tomorrow afternoon, we’ll reveal the New York Times article that included this graph and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.
(The next “What’s Going On in This Graph?” will be released tomorrow, Thursday, Feb. 28 with moderation on Wednesday, March 6.  The topic:  vaping.)

replies.comment info:

“I can assume that this red portion triggered the more constant change in the delays that is shown right when the segment ends.”  Let’s think about this.  
This scarf graph shows delays on a commuter line.  What would cause many, many days of delay (can you estimate the number of days, weeks, or months of the biggest red portion).
